column1: Compared to other tutorials/classes, how would you rate mine?

column10: Thanks so much for your help and enthusiasm! I found Psych 305 to be a really difficult class, but having you as a tutor helped me so much with the work content because your excitement made me get more excited about it, which helped me engage and learn better! I really loved having you teach us! All the best. :)

column3: I enjoyed the activities we did!! It was fun especially with how the content was pretty full on but the fact we got to discuss often with our peers was a good aspect for me. And the white board examples and the pictures helped immensely!!!! It made things so much easier to grasp so please continue that because reading of PowerPoint slides for me personally doesnâ€™t feel engaging

I also wish we got to discuss with more of our peers around the room, not just the people we sat with but I guess thatâ€™s kind of hard with the layout of the room

I found that integrating questions and making us think about the topic or slide you were talking about was helpful for me personally. It was fun and obvious you cared about making the lab worthwhile and teaching :)
column4: I think if there were ways to link ideas or correlations between the different labs/lab topics even more that would be useful for revision or making connections. Although you did already do this to a degree, it's the only feedback I can think of. Maybe more case studies like the documentary, but also with practical elements involved or integrating clinical neuroanatomy outcomes? I found in my other science courses when there is practical process like observing through a microscope or colour changes/fluorescence in a test tube, it helps me link the theory to what I'm seeing and remember or understand the theory behind it more.

column3:
Energy - which is hard to achieve in an 8am class! But concepts are always explained with energy and enthusiasm.
2) Positive tutor-student relationships. Students feel comfortable to ask for help when stuck on something.
3) Clarity of the instructions given. The labs often involve software that students are not familiar with and that have many steps to follow. These instructions are given clearly and the important parts emphasised/repeated, and help given if anyone gets stuck.
column4:
When thinking about the lab content, I realise I do have areas where I'm less confident in if I were being examined. 
All the theory work and explanations support the lecture content well and in this area I feel confident being examined on. However, when it comes to the lab activities working with the software etc., I realise that if this was on the exam, I wouldnâ€™t pass! 
Potentially, what might help future students is showing rather than doing when a student gets stuck. Also, explaining the â€˜whyâ€™ behind steps so that students can learn what exactly theyâ€™re doing and how to problem solve for themselves.
column10: I genuinely agree about having the labs be more activity-based rather than lecture recaps. Labs are the only opportunity students get to use the software that in future jobs many students will be expected to know how to use. The labs are not recorded, so the time in-lab is extremely valuable. Whereas lecture content can always be watched later if it was missed in-person! Additionally, if the lecture portion of lab time is reduced this would allow more time to learn the â€˜whyâ€™ behind each step of what to do in the activities - rather than rushing through to finish on time.
